case_name: Sons of Meda v. Buru and others

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1115 of 1966 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1115 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and decree dated November 18, 1965 of Punjab High Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 1169 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated November 18, 1965 of the Punjab High Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 1169 of 1962.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Shah, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J.

facts.text: Ram Sarup was the owner of a piece of land measuring 30 bighas 12 biswas.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Sarup was the owner of a piece of land measuring 30 bighas 12 biswas.

facts.text: Ram Sarup mortgaged without possession approximately 26 bighas of land to Meda by deed dated August 16, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: By a deed dated August 16, 1935, Ram Sarup mortgaged without possession a part of the land measuring approximately 26 bighas with one Meda.

facts.text: Ram Sarup mortgaged with possession the entire area of the land to Ananda on November 27, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Sarup on November 27, 1941, mortgaged with possession the entire area of the land to Ananda.

facts.text: Ram Sarup sold his rights in 27 bighas and 1 biswa of the land to Buru and others (plaintiffs) for Rs. 6,000 on May 14, 1943.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Sarup then sold his rights in 27 bighas and 1 biswa of the land on May 14, 1943 to Buru and others--who may be companylectively called the plaintiffs--for Rs. 6,000.

facts.text: Plaintiffs applied under s. 4 of Redemption of Mortgages Punjab Act 2 of 1913 for redeeming Meda mortgage on May 23, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs then applied on May 23, 1951, under s. 4 of the Redemption of Mortgages  Punjab  Act 2 of 1913 for redeeming the mortgage in favour of Meda.

facts.text: Application rejected on June 29, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: This application was rejected on June 29, 1951.

facts.text: Plaintiffs instituted suit for redemption of the mortgage on August 20, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the plaintiffs instituted on August 20, 1960, a suit in the civil companyrt for redemption of the mortgage.

facts.text: Suit resisted on ground that period of limitation under Art. 14 Indian Limitation Act 1908 expired.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was resisted, inter alia, on the ground that the period of limitation prescribed by Art. 14 of the Indian Limitation Act, 1908, had expired.

facts.text: Trial Court dismissed suit for redemption of Meda mortgage and granted decree for redemption of second mortgage dated November 27, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court dismissed the suit for redemption of the mortgage in favour of Meda, and granted a decree for redemption of the second mortgage dated November 27, 1941.

facts.text: Plaintiffs appealed to District Court, Gurgaon.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs appealed to the District Court, Gurgaon.

facts.text: District Court allowed appeal and ordered redemption including Meda mortgage.

anchor.surface_text: The District Court allowed the appeal and ordered redemption of the land including the mortgage in favour of Meda.

facts.text: Punjab High Court confirmed District Court decree in Regular Second Appeal No. 1169 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated November 18, 1965 of the Punjab High Court in Regular Second Appeal No. 1169 of 1962.

facts.text: Appeal preferred by sons of Meda.

anchor.surface_text: With special leave, this appeal has been preferred by sons of Meda.

facts.text: Record of proceedings before Assistant Collector destroyed before suit filed.

anchor.surface_text: The record of the proceedings before the Assistant Collector was, it was reported, destroyed before the suit was filed,

facts.text: Extract from register tendered in evidence with entry 'The application is rejected and should be companysigned to the record room.'

anchor.surface_text: and an extract from the register of redemption applications companyld be tendered in evidence. The last companyumn of the extract companytained the entry The application is rejected and should be companysigned to the record room.

facts.text: Endorsement on docket dated June 29, 1951: 'Application rejected. The petitioner has today been ordered to file a civil suit.'

anchor.surface_text: An endorsement on the docket maintained by the Advocate who appeared in the case before the Assistant Collector showed an endorsement dated June 29, 1951 Application rejected. The petitioner has today been ordered to file a civil suit.

facts.text: Trial Court, District Court, and High Court held Assistant Collector rejected petition because it raised complicated questions of fact and law not triable under summary jurisdiction of Act 2 of 1913.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court and the District Court held that the petition for redemption was number tried by the Assistant Collector he rejected the petition holding that the application raised companyplicated questions of fact and law, and on that account was number triable in exercise of the summary jurisdiction prescribed under Act 2 of 1913. With this view the High Court agreed.

facts.text: Appellants contend order of Assistant Collector became final under s.12 of Act and mortgagor could not sue after one year.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants companytends that the order of the Assistant Collector rejecting the petition under s. 4 of the Punjab Act 2 of 1913 became final by virtue of s. 12 of the Act and the mortgagor companyld number sue to redeem the mortgage in favour of Meda after the expiry of one year from the date of the order.

facts.text: Supreme Court disagreed that suit was barred by limitation under Art.14 Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to agree with the appellants companytention that since numbersuit was filed within one year of the date on which the application of the plaintiffs was rejected by the Assistant Collector, the order dismissing the application was companyclusive,

facts.text: No evidence that mortgagor declined to pay sum demanded by mortgagee.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberevidence that the mortgagor declined to pay the sum demanded by the mortgagee.

facts.text: Assistant Collector did not pass order dismissing petition for reasons recorded.

anchor.surface_text: Again the Assistant Collector did number pass an order dismissing the petition for any reasons recorded by him. He merely ordered that the case raised companyplicated questions of fact and law which companyld number be tried in a summary proceeding.

facts.text: Order of Assistant Collector does not fall within terms of s.9 of Act 2 of 1913.

anchor.surface_text: Such an order, in our judgment, does number fall within the terms of s. 9 of Act 2 of 1913.

concepts.unlisted_description: Empowers mortgagor to present petition to Collector for redemption order.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 12, Redemption of Mortgages (Punjab) Act 2 of 1913
concepts.unlisted_description: Aggrieved party may sue to establish rights; order conclusive subject to suit.

anchor.surface_text: the petition under s. 4 of the Punjab Act 2 of 1913 became final

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 4, Redemption of Mortgages (Punjab) Act 2 of 1913

anchor.surface_text: By s. 4 it is provided The mortgagor or other person entitled to institute a suit for redemption may, at any time after the principal money becomes payable and before a suit for redemption is barred, present a petition to the Collector applying for an order directing that his mortgage be redeemed, and where the mortgage is with possession that he be put in possession of the mortgaged property.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 4, Redemption of Mortgages (Punjab) Act 2 of 1913

anchor.surface_text: Section 8 provides Where both parties appear when the petition is called on for hearing, the Collector shall enquire from the mortgagee whether he admits that the petitioner is entitled to redeem, whether he is willing to accept the sum in deposit in full discharge of the mortgage debt, and where the mortgage is with possession whether he is willing to surrender possession of the mortgaged property. If the mortgagee replies in the affirmative, the Collector shall make an order as laid down in section 6 a ,  b ,  c  and  d  of this Act.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 8, Redemption of Mortgages (Punjab) Act 2 of 1913
concepts.unlisted_description: Procedure when both parties appear; enquiry from mortgagee.

anchor.surface_text: Section 9 on which reliance is primarily placed provides If the mortgagee raises objection on any ground other than the amount of the deposit, or if the petitioner is not willing to pay the sum demanded by the mortgagee, the Collector may either  a  for reasons to be recorded dismiss the petition, or  b  make a summary enquiry regarding the objection raised by the mortgagee or regarding the sum due.

concepts.interpretation: Authorises dismissal for reasons recorded only if objection other than deposit amount or mortgagor unwilling to pay; instant order rejecting for complexity not within terms.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: n 12 provides by the first paragraph Any party aggrieved by an order made under sections 6, 7, 8, 9, 10 or 11 of this Act may institute a suit to esta

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 9, Redemption of Mortgages (Punjab) Act 2 of 1913
concepts.unlisted_description: Collector may dismiss petition or enquire if objection raised.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 provides for enquiry into objections raised by the mortgagee,

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 10, Redemption of Mortgages (Punjab) Act 2 of 1913

anchor.surface_text: s. 11 provides for enquiry regarding the sum due under the mortgage and further provides for making deposit by the mortgagor within the period to be fixed by the Collector.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 11, Redemption of Mortgages (Punjab) Act 2 of 1913
concepts.unlisted_description: Enquiry on sum due and deposit.

anchor.surface_text: Section 12 provides by the first paragraph Any party aggrieved by an order made under sections 6, 7, 8, 9, 10 or 11 of this Act may institute a suit to establish his rights in respect of the mortgage but, subject to the result of such suit, if any, the order shall be conclusive.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 12, Redemption of Mortgages (Punjab) Act 2 of 1913

anchor.surface_text: Article 14 of Sch. 1 of the Limitation Act, 1908, provides that a suit to set aside any act or order of an officer of Government in his official capacity, not herein otherwise expressly provided for, shall be filed within one year of the date of the act or order.

issues.text: Whether the order of the Assistant Collector rejecting the petition under s. 4 of the Punjab Act 2 of 1913 became final by virtue of s. 12 of the Act and barred the mortgagor from suing to redeem the mortgage after expiry of one year under Art. 14 of the Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for the appellants contends that the order of the Assistant Collector rejecting the petition under s. 4 of the Punjab Act 2 of 1913 became final by virtue of s. 12 of the Act and the mortgagor could not sue to redeem the mortgage in favour of Meda after the expiry of one year from the date of the order.

issues.text: Whether the Assistant Collector's order rejecting the petition falls within the terms of s. 9 of the Redemption of Mortgages (Punjab) Act 2 of 1913.

anchor.surface_text: Such an order, in our judgment, does not fall within the terms of s. 9 of Act 2 of 1913.

issues.text: Whether the period of limitation prescribed by Art. 14 of the Limitation Act, 1908 applies to the Assistant Collector's order based on its substance rather than form.

anchor.surface_text: Even if by the order the petition was dismissed, not the form of the order, but its substance will determine the application of the period of limitation prescribed by Art. 14 of the Limitation Act.

issues.text: Whether the Assistant Collector's order is one required to be set aside as it bars the claim for redemption unless set aside, attracting Art. 14 limitation.

anchor.surface_text: An order required to be set aside is one which the officer making it has jurisdiction to make and has the effect of barring the claim for relief unless it is set aside.

issues.text: Whether the Assistant Collector's rejection was due to the matter raising complicated questions beyond the summary jurisdiction under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: the application raised complicated questions of fact and law, and on that account was not triable in exercise of the summary jurisdiction prescribed under Act 2 of 1913.

holdings.text: We are unable to agree with the appellants contention that since no suit was filed within one year of the date on which the application of the plaintiffs was rejected by the Assistant Collector, the order dismissing the application was conclusive, and the suit for redemption by the plaintiffs was not maintainable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order not under s.9(a) as no recorded reasons for specified grounds; substance does not bar redemption under Art.14; relegates to civil suit without affecting rights.

holdings.text: Such an order, in our judgment, does not fall within the terms of s. 9 of Act 2 of 1913.

anchor.surface_text: Such an order, in our judgment, does not fall within the terms of s. 9 of Act 2 of 1913.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.9(a) dismissal requires recorded reasons where mortgagee objects on non-deposit ground or petitioner unwilling to pay demanded sum; here merely complexity beyond summary proceeding, no evidence of unwillingness.

holdings.text: Even if by the order the petition was dismissed, not the form of the order, but its substance will determine the application of the period of limitation prescribed by Art. 14 of the Limitation Act.

anchor.surface_text: Even if by the order the petition was dismissed, not the form of the order, but its substance will determine the application of the period of limitation prescribed by Art. 14 of the Limitation Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Form irrelevant; substance governs whether order triggers Art.14 one-year limit to set aside govt officer acts.

holdings.text: An order required to be set aside is one which the officer making it has jurisdiction to make and has the effect of barring the claim for relief unless it is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: An order required to be set aside is one which the officer making it has jurisdiction to make and has the effect of barring the claim for relief unless it is set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.14 applies only to jurisdictional orders that bar relief; tested by effect on claim.

holdings.text: An order relegating the mortgagor to a civil suit for obtaining an order of redemption even if it becomes final does not bar a suit for redemption, for it raises no cloud on the title of the mortgagor arising out of the mortgage. Such an order is not one which is required to be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: An order relegating the mortgagor to a civil suit for obtaining an order of redemption even if it becomes final does not bar a suit for redemption, for it raises no cloud on the title of the mortgagor arising out of the mortgage.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order declares common law rights, directs civil suit, does not affect mortgage rights or bar redemption claim.

holdings.text: The Assistant Collector rejected the petition holding that the application raised complicated questions of fact and law, and on that account was not triable in exercise of the summary jurisdiction prescribed under Act 2 of 1913.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court and the District Court held that the petition for redemption was number tried by the Assistant Collector he rejected the petition holding that the application raised companyplicated questions of fact and law, and on that account was number triable in exercise of the summary jurisdiction prescribed under Act 2 of 1913. With this view the High Court agreed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepted lower courts' finding based on available records (extract, endorsement); Supreme Court relies on it for analysis.

anchor.surface_text: Tulsi Das v. Diala Ram 1 , Tek Chand, J., delivering the principal judgment of the Court dealt with the question which falls to be determined in this case. The learned Judge observed the suit referred to in s. 12 is to establish the erroneous nature of the order. Now what is the error companymitted by the Collector in his order which the mortgagor must seek to have set right by a declaratory suit ? No civil companyrt can grant a declaration that the Collectors view that the matter was too difficult for summary redemption was wrong and companypel him to proceed with the summary enquiry. The order of the Collector does number affect the rights of the parties in any way it is companyclusive to this extent only that the petition for summary redemption has been dismissed and numberother petition under the Act would lie.

precedents.cited_proposition: The order of the Collector dismissing the petition for summary redemption does not affect the rights of the parties under common law and does not require a suit under s. 12 to be set aside; it only bars further summary petitions under the Act, leaving the civil suit for redemption unaffected by limitation under Art. 14.
precedents.cited_holding: No civil court can grant a declaration that the Collector's view that the matter was too difficult for summary redemption was wrong and compel him to proceed with the summary enquiry. The order of the Collector does not affect the rights of the parties in any way it is conclusive to this extent only that the petition for summary redemption has been dismissed and no other petition under the Act would lie. No suit under s. 12 being necessary or competent, there was no bar to the mortgagor suing for redemption in the civil courts within the period allowed by law in ordinary course.

anchor.surface_text: The same view was expressed in a judgment of the Punjab High Court Dewan Chand v. Raghbir Singh 2 .

precedents.cited_proposition: The order of the Collector dismissing the petition for summary redemption does not bar a civil suit for redemption.
